required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan
(5) The social service supervisor shall approve,
countersign, and date the initial treatment plan.
Two of two initial treatment plans did not have the social service supervisor's
signature on the report.

CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan
(4) The social service worker shall sign and date the
initial treatment plan.
One of two initial treatment plans did not have the worker's signature present on
the report.
CCI Rule 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan
(4) The social service worker shall sign and date the
initial treatment plan.
Two of six updated treatment plans did not have the worker's signature present
on the report.
CCI Rule 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan
(5) The social service supervisor shall approve,
countersign, and date the updated treatment plan.
Four of six updated treatment plans did not have the social service supervisor's
signature present on the report.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Ensure all collateral contacts are listed in the service/treatment plans to show
the activities provided to the different youth. This should also include if a youth
refuses to participate in the activity.
• Develop a system of oversite to ensure each youth's file is reviewed for
compliance and have a system to document compliance and non-compliance
for training purposes.
• Ensure the kitchen cooler is monitored daily to ensure the running temperature
remains below 41F and take appropriate action to remove food if temperatures
are found to be above 41F. The high temperature was found during the
Environment inspection and the facility was able to make appropriate repairs
as documented in the Environmental inspection report.
• Ensure inspections are made of the kitchen area on a regular basis so any
damage can be repaired. During the Environmental inspection a wall near the

dry food storage was found and repairs were made as documented in the
Environmental inspection report.
• Ensure the storage rooms meet the fire inspection requirements as outlined in
the Fire Inspection report including providing a fire rated door, self-closing latch
allowing the door to close without assistance. This is documented as being
completed in the Fire Inspection report.
• Ensure wall and ceiling penetrations are sealed with approved fire-safing
materials are recommended in the Fire Inspection report. This is documented
as being completed in the Fire Inspection report.
• Ensure the doors for rooms storing combustible materials are equipped with
approved hydraulic door closers, specifically to the doors in the new addition.
This was a recommendation from the Fire Inspection report and the report
documents this has been accomplished.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
two corrective action plans submitted were the result of special investigations. The
first CAP was in response to special investigation 2025SIC0000044 which involved
3-action steps. These action steps included the staff involved receiving disciplinary
action, the staff involved in the incident being retrained and the staff having
restriction on the youth he can work with. The agency has implemented the plan
and is documented as occurring. The second CAP was in response to special
investigation 2025SIC0000010 which involved two action steps. The faulty piston
that was keeping the door from closing appropriately was removed and replaced
by a magnetic locking and all staff reviewed the facility’s supervision policies and
procedures with a focus on ensuring exit doors are secure especially when
someone is left alone in an area. The facility is following through with their actions
steps as required.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)

N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator outlines in the annual assessment that she has found no
areas of non-compliance during this period under review, nor has she found
barriers or systemic factors that have impacted the facility’s ability to stay in
compliance. The facility has hired and trained a new Social Service Worker to
ensure accuracy of service plans and to conduct regular audits of the service
plans. It is documented there have been no unplanned discharges during this
reporting period. This report identifies the two special investigations the facility
experienced. It is noted the facility’s policies and procedures were all reviewed in
November 2024 and the updated versions will be provided to licensing no later
than 12/30/2024.
Staff and Youth Interviews
The staff interviewed presented with very positive attitudes and all reported
enjoying their ability to provide for the youth in the program. Each reported being
dedicated to the wellbeing of the youth and all reported receiving a significant
amount of annual training to help improve their ability to provide best practice to
the youth. The staff shared disappoint in the Chief Administrator leaving but also
had a sense of optimism in the ability of the new Chief Administrator to provide
continued support to the staff.
Youth were observed during interactions with their assigned staff. Each staff was
attentive and provided redirection and had positive interactions with the youth. The
youth were very limited verbally and limited in their understanding of questions.
The youth were clean and well groomed.
Description of Agency Walk Through
This is a single-story facility well maintained and clean. Although, there is slight
damage, evidence suggests repairs are occurring on the damage as quickly as
possible. The damage is to the walls, and this is not uncommon with the issues the
youth present. All plumbing is in working order and the bedroom are furnished
appropriately. Medication is locked as required as are cleaning supplies and other
chemicals such as laundry detergent. The kitchen is well kept and there is an
abundance of fresh, frozen, and dry food. The menu is posted per policy and all
items required to be posted were found posted.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
